journal-title-group.journal-title: Quarterly Journal of Finance and Accounting

title-group.article-title: Looking for Earnings Management in Corporate Defined Benefit Pension Plans

abstract.p: Bergstresser, Desai and Rauh (2006) present statistical evidence of firms engaging in earnings management whereby managers opportunistically choose an expected rate of return (ERR) for their defined benefit pension plan that positively impacts profits. Firms with larger pension funds relative to profits are thought to have more motivation to manipulate ERR. A model of ERR was tested on data from 1992-2002. I apply the model data for 2003-2011 and find no evidence of such behavior. This finding cannot be attributed to recent changes in pension accounting rules that enhance transparency. I find that pension fund size alone can explain a good portion of variation in ERR. However, the inclusion of firm fixed effects is able to capture over 90% of the variation in ERR, leaving little role for earnings management.
